articleTitle: Central Zone Size Dependence of Peripheral Dimming Technique Under Wide Field of View Environment
xml:
SECTION I.

Introduction

Augmented reality (AR) and virtual reality (VR) technologies have been applied to various fields [1], [2]. It is expected that they have a high potential to change our entertainment and working behavior. A head-mounted display (HMD) devices are commonly used to provide AR/VR experience. With the advancement of AR/VR technology, HMD devices have been steadily developed. Especially, the performance of the display has become important in order to provide more realistic and immersive environment. Due to the advantages of high contrast ratio, color reproduction, and flexibility, emissive displays have been expected to play a stronger role in next-generation HMD devices [3].

Emissive displays, in which each pixel in the display is a light emitter, are emerging in the display market. Organic light-emitting diode (OLED) displays and micro light-emitting diode (micro-LED) displays are representative emissive displays. They are used in various applications such as HMD, smartphones, tablets, and televisions. Emissive displays have several advantages such as thinness, high contrast, power efficiency, and flexibility [4], [5], [6], [7]. For example, OLED displays consume less power than liquid crystal displays (LCDs) with the same perceived brightness as displays for mobile devices [8]. For those reasons, LCDs have recently been replaced by OLED displays in mobile devices. Nevertheless, a display itself is still one of the major power consumers in mobile devices [9], [10]. Power efficiency is an important issue in mobile devices. Therefore, numerous techniques are currently being studied in various approaches to reduce the power consumption of emissive displays.

In contrast to LCDs, in which power consumption is affected by the backlight, the power consumption of emissive display is dependent on the electric current flowing through each subpixel. Thus, the power consumption of emissive displays is affected by the color and brightness of the image and the pixel density [11], [12], [13], [14]. Dong and Zhong attempted to reduce power consumption using color transformation techniques that change the color schemes of graphical user interfaces (GUIs) [12] and web pages [14]. They work similarly to the dark theme or dark mode, which are used in smartphones. These techniques can effectively reduce power consumption, but they can only be used for certain content. Adjustment of the color and brightness of an image is a simple and effective method for saving power. However, it should be applied carefully because color and brightness are strongly related to image quality. To address this issue, two approaches have been considered: one approach is to adjust the color and brightness to a level unnoticeable to the observer. Park and Song proposed a color blending scheme that reduces brightness while minimizing the degradation of visual impact [15]. Choi et al. described the technique of adaptive color saturation based on the principle of a just noticeable color difference [16]. In addition to these techniques, contrast enhancement [17], [18], [19] and tone mapping method [20] have achieved power savings while minimizing degradation of image quality. Another approach is to adjust the color or brightness of the unperceived area of the display. Some methods operate by turning off subpixels either in the GUI [21] or in the screen areas covered by the user’s fingers [22]. Local dimming techniques based on visual attention have also been reported to reduce power consumption without the visual degradation of image quality [23], [24], [25]. They efficiently reduced power consumption by darkening the less important area on the screen. However, they have limitations because the darkened area is still visible to the user.

To overcome these problems, we studied a low-power display technique based on gaze tracking called peripheral dimming [26]. It aims to be a gaze-contingent technique that works in response to the user’s gaze position. The darkened area would be barely noticeable to the user. As a result, it can maintain perceived image quality while reducing power consumption. This low-power technique for emissive displays requires an eye tracking. HMD systems have evolved towards incorporating multiple sensors for various capture, tracking, and other functions. Especially, the eye tracking is expected to be one of them [27]. Thus, it is expected that eye-tracker integrated HMD devices will become common. Whereas these developments have provided users with more improved experience, they have also led to higher power consumption. Thus, in terms of saving power consumption, our technique will be useful to the HMD devices.

The peripheral dimming technique divides an image into two zones: a central zone and a peripheral zone. The central zone is a circular area centered on the gaze point and the peripheral zone is the area outside the central zone. The pixels in the central zone maintain their image data without any modification. On the other hand, the luminance in the peripheral zone gradually decreases as the distance from the end of the central zone to the gaze position increases. In our previous study [26], the size of the central zone was determined to be 10°, which sufficiently covers the fovea (~5°) and parafovea (~5°–9°) [28]. Because, however, the HMD device has a wide field of view (FoV) of 100° or more, it is possible that the central zone size (CZS) of 10° may not be an optimal condition. Thus, we decided to investigate both the validity of the technique under a wide FoV environment and the effects of the CZS on the peripheral dimming technique. under a wide FoV environment.

This study aims to investigate the threshold dimming levels and power-saving efficiency ($\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ ) depending on CZS. Herein, the threshold is defined as a maximum dimming level where the observer cannot notice any changes in the brightness of the image. Threshold levels for three CZSs were obtained through a psychophysical experiment. The effects of the CZS were investigated using statistical analyses.

SECTION II.

Peripheral Dimming Technique

A. Motive

A human visual field is distinguished into two main areas: foveal and peripheral visions. Lots of studies have reported that two visual fields have different visual characteristics. It is known that the difference is caused by non-uniform spatial distribution of photoreceptors [28]. The cone cells that mediate photopic vision are densely packed in the fovea and rapidly decrease in number toward the periphery of the retina [29]. Thus, as widely known, the foveal vision has significantly higher visual acuity and spatial resolution than peripheral vision. Furthermore, it has been reported that the peripheral vision has relatively weaker perception of size, color, brightness than the foveal vision [30], [31], [32], [33], [34]. A study that brightness-difference threshold increases with increasing eccentricity attracted our attention [34]. For this reason, we assumed that users might not notice any visual difference even brightness decreases in their peripheral vision. If image data are darkened in the peripheral vision, power consumption of the display could be saved while maintaining the perceived image quality.

B. Perceived Brightness

The peripheral dimming technique achieves power savings by gradually reducing brightness in the peripheral vision area. In other words, it reduces luminance of the corresponding display area. Visual perception is not proportional to luminance [35]. Human perception of changes in luminance would vary depending on current luminance value. For example, the human eyes sensitively notice luminance changes of dark images. On the other hand, they are less sensitive to detecting luminance changes of bright images. In addition, the luminance level depends on the devices. For universal application of the technique, image and device-independent brightness condition is essential. Thus, we determined dimming conditions based on the visual perception instead of luminance. Brightness refers to the perceived amount of light, but it is not suitable to the technique because it is a non-quantitative reference to physiological sensations [36]. To quantitatively reflect human visual perception, the CIELAB color space was used in the technique. This color space was proposed for a perceptually uniform space where a given numerical change corresponds to a similar perceived change in color. It consists of three components of L*, a*, and b*. Herein, a* and b* together represent chroma, and L* indicates lightness intended to match a subjective perception of light. The lightness component (L*) can be calculated by (1) and (2):\begin{align*} L^{\ast }=&116 h\left ({\frac {Y_{d}}{Y_{ref}} }\right)-16,\tag{1}\\ h\left ({t }\right)=&\begin{cases} \displaystyle t^{\frac {1}{3}}, &t>\left ({\frac {6}{29} }\right)^{3} \\ \displaystyle \frac {1}{3}\left ({\frac {29}{6} }\right)^{2}t+\frac {4}{29},& otherwise. \end{cases}\tag{2}\end{align*} View Source\begin{align*} L^{\ast }=&116 h\left ({\frac {Y_{d}}{Y_{ref}} }\right)-16,\tag{1}\\ h\left ({t }\right)=&\begin{cases} \displaystyle t^{\frac {1}{3}}, &t>\left ({\frac {6}{29} }\right)^{3} \\ \displaystyle \frac {1}{3}\left ({\frac {29}{6} }\right)^{2}t+\frac {4}{29},& otherwise. \end{cases}\tag{2}\end{align*} $\text{Y}_{\mathrm {d}}$ and $\text{Y}_{\mathrm {ref}}$ denote the luminance of a certain pixel and white pixel, respectively. The lightness value ranges from 0 to 100 that corresponds to from black to white, respectively.

C. Lightness Reductino Ratio and Central Zone Size

Fig. 1 illustrates a framework of the peripheral dimming technique. Firstly, the color space conversion is performed to obtain the L* values. An RGB color space is converted to the CIELAB color space. Thereafter, the L* values of the pixels are multiplied by the weight values that range from 0 to 1. Fig. 2(a) shows an example of the weight map with the CZS of 10°. The weight value within the central zone is 1, and it linearly decreases outside the central zone. The degree of lightness reduction depending on the viewing is defined as the lightness reduction ratio (LRR). Herein, the lightness can also decrease non-linearly. However, a linear model which is the simplest condition was used for minimizing variables because it needs more time to find out the optimal model. Consequently, while maintaining the lightness of the central zone, the peripheral zone gradually is darkened with increased viewing angle. The weight map is computed based on the LRR value and is multiplied to the $\text{L}\ast $ domain. Finally, the weight-applied CIELAB color space is converted to the RGB color space, and then the image is displayed.

Figs. 2(a) and 2(b) show two weight maps for the same LRR but different CZS. The graphs describe the weight values of the horizontal pixels neighboring the fixation point. In the peripheral dimming technique, the degree of brightness reduction at the screen’s edge depends on the central zone size. Even if the same LRR is applied, the smaller CZS results in a much darker edge of the screen as shown in Fig. 2(a). If darkening of the peripheral zone is noticeable, the LRR should be reduced. If then, that leads to a decrease in power-saving efficiency. Consequently, CZS may need to be adjusted appropriately depending on the FoV condition. To solve this issue, the effects of the CZS on the power-saving efficiency should be verified.

SECTION III.

Experiment

A. Participants

Twenty participants (six males and 14 females) with normal or corrected-to-normal visual acuity participated in the experiment, and 19 participants completed the experiment. The ages of the participants ranged from 20 to 27 years (mean 23.0).

B. Experimental Setup

Fig. 3 shows the experimental setup. Experiments were conducted in a dark room. A chin rest was used to fix the position of the head of the observer. A 43-inch LCD monitor with a resolution of $3840\times2160$ pixels was used. The monitor was placed 60 cm away from the chin rest. The horizontal and vertical fields of view were 76.2° and 47.6°, respectively. A screen-based eye tracker was used to monitor the participants’ gaze positions. The recommended setup position of the eye tracker was under the display. Thus, to accurately detect the participant’s eyes, it was placed at the bottom of the screen. The gaze data were recorded at a sampling rate of 60 Hz. The participants answered questions by typing on a keypad.

FIGURE 3.

The experimental setup.

Show All

C. Stimuli

Fig. 4(a) shows an image used in the experiment. A monochromatic image with a resolution of $3840 \times 2160$ pixels was used. The original image was a full-color image with a $4000\times 2246$ resolution released under Creative Commons CC0 [37]. To remove the effect of color on the perception of brightness, the color image was converted to a gray image. A rgb2gray function in MATLAB was used for the gray scale conversion. Thereafter, the image resolution was adjusted to $3840\times 2160$ by the imresize function in MATLAB. The gaze position was fixed at the center of the screen. The gaze position was indicated by a red cross with a size of 1°. Three CZSs of 10°, 25°, and 40° were used in the experiment. Three CZSs are drawn to scale in Fig. 4(b).

FIGURE 4.

(a) An image used in the experiment and (b) the sizes of central zone.

D. Experimental Design

The experiment was designed using the Psychophysics Toolbox extensions in MATLAB [38], [39], [40]. An interval two-alternative forced-choice (2-AFC) method was used. Fig. 5 illustrates the sequence of each trial. Each trial began with a startup sound, and a fixation image was displayed for three seconds. Thereafter, the reference (original) and test (dimmed) images were sequentially displayed for three seconds in random order. A blank image was inserted between the two images for 1.5 seconds. After the second image, the participants were asked to select the brighter image, that is the original image, within five seconds. Participants made their selection using a keypad. Each trial took approximately 16 seconds.

FIGURE 5.

Schematic diagram of the assessment procedure.

Show All

The 1 up/3 down (1u3d) staircase method was employed to obtain the LRRTH. The staircase began with a sufficiently high LRR level where the dimmed region was pronounced. The initial LRR levels were 0.7, 1.0, and 1.3%/° for the 10, 25, and 40° sizes of central zone, respectively. In each trial, participants were asked to select the brighter image. The subsequent LRR level was lowered by one step after three consecutive correct responses or was raised by one step after one incorrect response. The step size was varied depending on the number of reversals of direction along the staircase, as described in Table 1. The staircase was terminated after 18 reversals.

TABLE 1 The Step Size Depending on the Number of Reversals

E. Experimental Procedure

Participants fixed their heads on the chin rest during the experiment. The eye-tracker was then calibrated for each participant. Prior to the experiment, the participants performed a short training session. In the training session, the participants experienced two things: an allowed gaze zone and a high LRR condition. We informed participants that a beep sounds when their gaze is outside the allowed gaze zone. They were asked to concentrate again and to gaze at the center when the beep sounds. The allowed gaze zone was an invisible circular area centered on the fixation point with a size of 8°. The beep sounded at every moment when the gaze moves out of the fixation window, at every second if the gaze stays outside the allowed gaze zone. If the beep sounded more than three times within one trial, the answer was not recorded and the trial with the same conditions was repeated. Next, a test image with a high LRR was presented to participants as an example. Every participant could easily notice the lightness difference between the reference and high LRR images, which helped the participants to understand the experimental procedure. The CZS was randomly selected at either 10°, 25°, or 40°. The trial sequence was repeated until the termination condition for the 1u3d staircase method was satisfied. To prevent the fatigue effect, there was a one-minute break for every six reversals. When the 1u3d staircase was completed for one size of central zone, the participants took a break for two minutes. Thereafter, a 1u3d staircase with different CZSs was performed. The entire procedure, including the short training session and breaks, took approximately 105 minutes per participant.

SECTION IV.

Results

A. Dependence of LRRth on the CZS

LRRTH was estimated by averaging the LRR levels over the final 10 reversals. Fig. 6(a) describes the five-number summary of data: the minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, and maximum. In Fig. 6(a), the whisker represents the minimum and maximum values, and the box represents the others. The circles denote the individual LRRTH data. Fig. 6(b) shows the averages and standard deviations (SDs) of the data. To verify the significance of differences among the groups, a repeated-measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) was performed. Data were analyzed using the Statistical Package for Social Sciences ver. 25 [41]. Firstly, Mauchly’s test for the sphericity assumption that the variances of differences are not significantly different was performed. The Mauchly’s test results indicated that the assumption of sphericity was met in the repeated-measures ANOVA; $\chi ^{2}(2) = 3.26$ , $p = 0.20$ . The repeated-measures ANOVA results indicated that at least one of the three groups was significantly different ($F(2, 36) = 46.57$ , $p < 0.01$ ). A pairwise comparison results are illustrated in Fig. 6(b). The results revealed that all groups were significantly different.

FIGURE 6.

(a) Boxplot and (b) Scatter plot of LRRTH depending on the CZS, with error bars displayed.

Show All

The average LRRTH were 0.28, 0.43, and 0.77%/° for the CZSs of 10, 25, and 40°, respectively. The average LRRTH increased with the CZS. Interestingly, the LRRTH distributions also became larger with increased CZS. Table 2 describes the average and quartile LRRTHs. In addition to the mean or median, the LRR level can be determined within the range from Q1 to Q3 depending on the users’ preference. To determine LRRTH within this range could provide various options for applying the technique either conservatively or aggressively.

TABLE 2 LRRTH Values on Average and Quartiles

B. Power-Saving Efficiency

The power consumption was estimated using a power modeling method presented by Dong et al. [42]. Equation (3) describes the power consumption in a subpixel (P) of an OLED display.\begin{equation*} P\left ({D }\right)=\omega \times D^{\gamma },\tag{3}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} P\left ({D }\right)=\omega \times D^{\gamma },\tag{3}\end{equation*} where $\omega $ and D denote the weighting component and the digital RGB data, respectively. Different weighting values were assigned to red, green, and blue subpixels. The values of $\omega _{\mathrm {r}}$ , $\omega _{\mathrm {g}}$ , and $\omega _{\mathrm {b}}$ were 70, 115, and 154, respectively. 2.2 was used for the exponent $\gamma $ in this study. The total dissipated power (TDP) of an OLED display was calculated by summing the power of all RGB subpixels as in (4).\begin{equation*} TDP=\sum \nolimits _{i=1}^{N} \sum \nolimits _{j=1}^{M} \left \{{P_{R}\left ({i,j }\right)+P_{G}\left ({i,j }\right)+P_{B}(i,j) }\right \},\tag{4}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} TDP=\sum \nolimits _{i=1}^{N} \sum \nolimits _{j=1}^{M} \left \{{P_{R}\left ({i,j }\right)+P_{G}\left ({i,j }\right)+P_{B}(i,j) }\right \},\tag{4}\end{equation*} where i and j denote the horizontal and vertical indices of the pixel, respectively. N and M denote the number of horizontal and vertical pixels, respectively. In this case their values were 3840 and 2160, respectively. $\text{P}_{\mathrm {R}}$ , $\text{P}_{\mathrm {G}}$ , and $\text{P}_{\mathrm {B}}$ are the power consumed in red, green, and blue subpixels, respectively. We calculated the TDP of the original (TDP$_{\mathrm {ORG}}$ ) and peripherally dimmed images (TDP$_{\mathrm {PD}}$ ). Thereafter, we obtained power-saving efficiency ($\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ ) values using (5).\begin{equation*} \eta _{power}=\left({1-\frac {TDP_{PD}}{TDP_{ORG}}}\right)\times 100.\tag{5}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \eta _{power}=\left({1-\frac {TDP_{PD}}{TDP_{ORG}}}\right)\times 100.\tag{5}\end{equation*}

The calculated $\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ values are listed in Table 3. We expected that $\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ would be influenced by the CZS. However, interestingly, the resulting values of $\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ were similar for all sizes of central zone. The power consumption was reduced by approximately 12% on average. Considering the difference in individual preference, the technique can achieve power-saving by approximately 8% to 15%. Except for the third quartile results, $\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ slightly decreased with increased CZS as shown in Table 3. To investigate whether those slight differences are statistically significant, the repeated measures ANOVA was performed. The power-saving efficiency values corresponding to the individual LRRTH were calculated, and the distribution was compared. The Mauchly’s test results indicated that the assumption of sphericity is met in the repeated measures ANOVA; $\chi 2(2) = 1.79$ , p $=0.41$ . The repeated measures ANOVA revealed that there was no statistically significant difference among groups (F(2,36) $=0.44$ , p $=0.65$ ). There was no apparent trend for $\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ to increase or to decrease depending on the CZS. It means that the peripheral dimming can achieve similar power-saving efficiency regardless of the CZS. In terms of power-saving efficiency, thus, the CZS can be determined freely depending on image content.

C. Average Lightness of the Image

Because brightness is closely related to the power consumption of emissive displays, we analyzed the average lightness (AL) of the image. The AL of the image was calculated as follows:\begin{equation*} AL=\frac {1}{({res}_{x}+{res}_{y})}\sum \nolimits _{i=1}^{res_{x}} \sum \nolimits _{j=1}^{res_{y}} L_{(i,j)}^{\ast },\tag{6}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} AL=\frac {1}{({res}_{x}+{res}_{y})}\sum \nolimits _{i=1}^{res_{x}} \sum \nolimits _{j=1}^{res_{y}} L_{(i,j)}^{\ast },\tag{6}\end{equation*} where i and j denote the horizontal and vertical indices of a pixel, respectively. $\text{L}^{\ast }_{\mathrm {(i,j)}}$ denotes the lightness value of the pixel (i, j). The resx and resy denote the horizontal and vertical resolutions of the image, respectively. Fig. 7(a) shows the individual AL of the image adopting LRRTH obtained by the individual for each CZS. The red dashed line denotes the AL of the original image, with a value of 72.9. The symbols denote the individual results. Interestingly, in most individual results, the difference in AL depending on the CZS was very small, as shown in Fig. 7(b). In this graph, the blue dots and error bars denote the average AL and SD of all participants. The detailed values are listed in Table 4. The results for not only the mean AL but also the SD showed similar values for all CZSs. The repeated measures ANOVA was performed. The assumption of sphericity was met in the repeated measures ANOVA ($\chi ^{2}(2) = 2.05$ , $p = 0.36$ ) and the ANOVA results indicated no significant difference ($F(2,36) = 0.08$ , $p = 0.92$ ).

SECTION V.

Discussion

A. Fatigue Effect

The staircase method was designed to repeat trials until 18 reversals. On average, approximately 85 trials were performed per each staircase. This termination condition was determined to minimize the standard deviation of the threshold [43]. Even though we provided the observers with a break at regular intervals, holding a fixation for a long time may cause visual fatigue. If fatigue had an effect, a trend of increasing LRRTH would be observed as the number of trials or the session order increased. A large LRRTH indicates lower visual sensitivity. To investigate if the fatigue had effects on the experiment, we analyzed the individual LRR$_{\mathrm {TH}}\text{s}$ depending on the number of trials. Firstly, Spearman’s correlation was computed to assess the relationship between them. To exclude the individual differences, an increase rate compared to LRRTH of the CZS of 10° were analyzed, instead of LRRTH values. The increase rate was calculated as follows:\begin{equation*} \mathrm {increase~rate}=\frac {({LRR}_{comp}-{LRR}_{ref})}{LRR_{ref}},\tag{7}\end{equation*} View Source\begin{equation*} \mathrm {increase~rate}=\frac {({LRR}_{comp}-{LRR}_{ref})}{LRR_{ref}},\tag{7}\end{equation*} where LRRcomp and LRRref denote the LRRTH values of the CZS of 25° (or 40°) and 10°, respectively. Fig. 8 shows the increase rates depending on the number of trials. No significant correlation was observed for both results: Spearman’s correlation coefficients ($\text{r}_{\mathrm {s}}$ ) were close to zero (25°: $r_{s}= 0.23$ , $p = 0.35$ , 40°: $r_{s} = -0.04$ , $p = 0.88$ ). Therefore, we concluded that visual fatigue did not significantly affect the experiment.

B. Effect of the CZS

Fig. 6(a) showed interesting results that the change in CZS affected the individual variations as well as the mean value of LRRTH. We think that it was due to the property of the staircase method used in the experiment. In the staircase method, as described in Table 1, a fixed step size of LRR was used. The size of the peripheral zone is inversely proportional to the size of the central zone. Thus, even if the LRR is slightly changed under the small CZS, the overall lightness of the image would change more significantly than a larger CZS. For that reason, although the step size of the LRR was the same for all CZS conditions, the overall lightness change of the image was not the same. The minimum AL change under the CZS of 10° may have been large enough to be noticed even by the participants who are visually insensitive. On the other hand, the minimum AL change under the large CZS condition may be a subtle brightness change relatively. We think that this factor led to differences in the results between the visually sensitive and insensitive groups, and thus, the distribution was broadened under the large CZS condition.

In Fig. 6(b), it was observed that the average LRRTH was positively correlated with the CZS. On the other hand, there was no significant difference in $\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ depending on CZS as described in Table 3. This finding demonstrates that an CZS of 10° is applicable even in a wide FoV environment, and that the peripheral dimming technique can achieve consistent energy efficiency regardless of the CZS. Therefore, the size of the central zone can be flexibly determined depending on the target applications or content. Each size of the central zone has its pros and cons. For example, a large distribution in LRRTH was observed with increased CZS conditions. From the viewpoint of determining the LRRTH value, the large CZS might be worse due to a difficulty to determine the representative value. Consequently, it may be necessary to determine the value of LRR more conservatively when the technique is applied with a larger CZS. On the other hand, when the small CZS is applied, if the image processing speed does not keep up with the rapid eye movement, such as saccadic eye movement, the dimmed area may be seen in the fovea more easily. This problem would be more noticeable with small CZS. Thus, a large CZS could have an advantage in this issue. Thus, the CZS should be determined taking these characteristics into account.

C. Consistency of Al Changes

Contrary to the results of LRRTH, interestingly, the average lightness (AL) of the image adopting LRRTH had a steady distribution even if the CZS was different as shown in Fig. 7(b). We tried to find an appropriate LRRTH depending on various conditions to apply the peripheral dimming without degradation of the perceived image quality. Fortunately, the AL of the image could be a key factor for the technique. LRRTH depends on CZS. Thus, to estimate an appropriate LRR value that meet the conditions is not easy. If the AL change is consistent or has a common trend for other images, it could be feasible to estimate LRRTH by computing the AL change. If then, an appropriate LRR condition can be estimated more easily. That assumption is based on consistent AL changes, but there is a difficulty to verify it in this study. Therefore, further studies should be performed to verify this hypothesis.

D. Experimental Limitations

Our findings were obtained for a monochromic image as shown in Fig. 4(a). The colors are strongly related to the brightness perception. The Helmholtz–Kohlrausch effect, which is a perceptual phenomenon wherein the intense saturation of spectral hue is perceived as part of the color’s luminance, is an example. Thus, we could not generalize the experimental results for full color images. The expected power-saving efficiency of the technique might be limited to monochromatic images. However, the fundamental principle to reduce the luminance of the peripheral zone will be still valid. Therefore, although the efficiency of the technique may vary depending on the type of image, it will succeed to reduce the power consumption of the displays.

The FoV condition used in the experiment was $76.2^{\circ }\times 47.6^{\circ }$ . Even though the FoV was improved compared to the previous study [26], it was still smaller than the current HMD devices with the FoV of approximately 100°. Our FoV condition was limited due to the operating distance of the eye tracker. Our findings indicated that the AL change is consistent. Thus, it is considered that the $\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ for the same image will remain constant even as the FoV increases. However, contrary to our expectations, the impact of FoV may be significant. This is possible because the reduction in lightness of the image increases as the FoV is larger. This issue should be verified through the experimental data in our future work.

The peripheral dimming technique aims to be a gaze-contingent technique, so it requires eye tracking. Thus, if this additional component consumes power more than the technique saves, the technique could be meaningless. However, we think that the benefits from our technique would not be canceled out if the technique is applied to eye-tracker integrated HMD devices. Integrating an eye tracker in the HMD devices can offer various novel functions. For example, the eye tracking can be used for emotion recognition or health care such as clinical diagnosis [44], [45], [46]. To expand the application of the HMD device, the eye tracker would be a key component. Even today, either the wearable display devices with integrated eye tracker or the eye-tracking add-ons for HMD devices are on the market [47], [48]. Therefore, as mentioned in the introduction section, we believe that the eye-tracker integrated HMD devices will become pervasive. Consequently, if eye tracking technology becomes more common in HMD device, i.e. the power consumed in eye tracking is not an additional cost anymore, the peripheral dimming technique will effectively reduce the net power of the devices.

SECTION VI.

Conclusion

In this study, the dependency of the CZS in the peripheral dimming technique was investigated. A psychophysical experiment with the CZSs of 10, 25, and 40° was performed to determine the threshold conditions where power could be saved while maintaining perceived image quality. The experimental results showed that the average and standard deviation of LRRTH depend on the CZS. On the other hand, the differences in $\eta _{\mathrm {power}}$ depending on the CZS were not statistically significant. It was demonstrated that the peripheral dimming technique with any CZS is feasible in a wide FoV environment. These findings indicate that the CZS can be adjusted flexibly depending on image content or the users’ preference. The technique can reduce power consumption of the display panel by approximately 12% on average, up to 15% when it is applied aggressively. However, if the eye tracker is used by default such as HMD device with integrated eye tracker, the technique will help to reduce the net power of the device. HMD devices provide various content with a wide FoV and require low-power operation. Consequently, when eye-tracking HMD devices become pervasive, the peripheral dimming technique will be an attractive solution to save power consumption.
